Name: 1_passed away_grandmother_mary_memorial
Representative_Docs: ['Mary Louise Nichols Birth: 1948 Death: 2025 August 14, 1948 December 5, 2025 Mary Louise Nichols (nee Mary Louise Assel, age 77 passed away peacefully on December 5, 2025. She was born on August 14, 1948 in Chico, CA to her parents Albert and Gloria Assell and attended schools in Chico, graduating from Chico Senior High School in 1966. Mary married her loving husband, Will (‚ÄúBill‚Äù) Nichols, also of Chico, on June 21, 1968. Will and Mary were married for 57 years. Mary put her family above all else and was a dedicated wife, mother, grandmother, sister, and aunt. Mary was active in the Chico community. For many years, before her retirement from Chico Unified School District, she pursued her passion for teaching elementary school children to read. She was a member of local chapters of both the charitable organizations of Omega Nu and PEO. She enjoyed spending her free time in Chico golfing with Will and friends, playing tennis, volunteering at her children‚Äôs schools, attending dance club, and socializing with friends and neighbors. Although Mary was a lifetime resident of Chico, she spent much of her time in the mountains at her cabins in Bucks Lake and Whitehawk Ranch and at her family home in the beach', 'Mary Kuljis Fiamengo Birth: 1934 Death: 2025 Mary Fiamengo passed away peacefully on November 6, 2025. Mary was born on September 20, 1934 in Komiza, Croatia. She was preceded in death by her beloved husband, Pete J. Fiamengo. Mary was a devoted wife, mother, sister, grandmother, great grandmother, aunt and dear friend. She is survived by her daughters, Deborah Dwight and Jennifer (Tim) Lovoy; her grandchildren, Peter Dwight (Cassandra), John Lovoy (Sloane), Ellen (Justin) Ralph and Lauren Dwight (Tim); her great grandchildren, Jordana Koonce, Hank Ralph and Margot Dwight and her sister, Betty Galosic. She was a long standing member of Mary Star of the Sea Church Velike Gospe Society, San Pedro Peninsula Cancer Guild and San Pedro Peninsula Hospital Bookworm Guild. Mary was a woman of grace, elegance and kindness; always extending a gentle word, a thoughtful gesture or a warm embrace. A memorial mass will be held at 10:30 am on Monday, November 17, 2025 at Mary Star of the Sea Catholic Church. In lieu of flowers, Mary requested that a donation in her memory be made to the San Pedro Peninsula Cancer Guild or to Mary Star of the Sea High School. Send Flowers Plant a Tree Send a Meal', 'Linda Sue (Jordan) Schlosser Birth: 1950 Death: 2025 Linda Sue (Jordan) Schlosser March 16, 1950-December 15, 2025 passed away peacefully surrounded by her family at her home in San Pancho, Mexico. Survived by her husband of 41 years, Phil Schlosser, her mother Gerry, daughter Kelly Noel, son Kevin Noel and wife Jennifer and her grandchildren Trevor and Lena. She was preceded in death by her father, Wayne Henry Jordan and brother Michael Wayne Jordan. Linda was born and raised in San Rafael, CA and graduated from Terra Linda High School. Linda loved sunshine, warm weather and travel. She was an outstanding cook and loved to entertain. Her great adventure was moving to Mexico, building a wonderful home filled with warmth, family, friends and great meals. She loved traveling throughout Mexico and Italy. Her family requests that gifts in lieu of flowers be made in Linda‚Äôs name to St. Jude Children‚Äôs Research Hospital. Forever deep in my soul, The memory of your love Fills my heart And I am never alone. Honor with Flowers In memory of Linda Sue Plant a Living Memorial In memory of Linda Sue']

Name: 2_family_family members_gifts_friendships
Representative_Docs: ['Asking Eric: Family, friends don‚Äôt seem to appreciate time I put into tedious Christmas cookie tradition Dear Eric: My late mother made a special Christmas cookie that required tedious decorating, considering each person‚Äôs personal preference for toppings, and giving them as gifts to family and friends. They always had a place of honor on our family Christmas table. When she was no longer able, she gave me the cookie cutter, and my daughters and I took over the family tradition. It takes the three of us several days to make, bake, decorate, package and mail cookies to family members around the country. We enjoy doing it and feel like we‚Äôre continuing the fun and festive tradition. However, in recent years, not all of the recipients acknowledge receipt. At some point in their lives, they have all helped Grandma decorate, so they know the time involved. Because of past delivery issues, I track the boxes and inquire if I haven‚Äôt heard from them in a couple of days. Last year, one response was ‚Äúyes we got them.‚Äù This feels unappreciative! In the past most would text a picture of their children with the cookies, which we really enjoyed. We rarely see any of them anymore, as they are busy raising their families and don‚Äôt live nearby. This seems like a way for us to continue somewhat of a co', 'Asking Eric: Can mom work through tension in son‚Äôs relationship with dad so they can celebrate special birthday? Dear Eric: My son is turning 40 on December 22. My husband and I are at a quandary as to how to celebrate him. There have been issues between my husband and him over things from his childhood. We did a special trip for his older brother when he turned 40 and would like to do something special for this son‚Äôs 40th as well. Our daughter-in-law has made special plans for him and we are not included. I understand that, but I need some ideas as to how to celebrate this extra special year without rocking the boat. I love my son with all my heart, as I do all my children, and want his 40th birthday to be memorable in a positive way. Any suggestions? ‚Äì Mom Who Wants to Celebrate Dear Mom: The issues your son and your husband are having may be an obstacle, but they aren‚Äôt insurmountable. And the thing that can get them on the path to resolution is the same thing that can get you answers about how to celebrate your son: open communication. It‚Äôs not within your purview to try to fix things between them, but you have your own relationship with your son and so I‚Äôd encourage you to reach out and tell him what you told me: you want to celebrate him, you know things are difficult, and you‚Äôre lookin', 'Asking Eric: After 6 years sober, man is frustrated by his family‚Äôs hold on their hurt and distrust Dear Eric: I‚Äôve just turned 40 this past year. The last 15 years I was in a horrible drug addiction. I lied and hurt and did terrible things to a lot of people, especially my family. About eight years ago they officially disowned me. Understandable. I‚Äôve cleaned up and got my act together six years ago. At first, I tried to force my way back into their lives, which all refuted. I lashed out, said horrible things and stopped trying to be in their lives. My mom will stop by on my birthday for 10 minutes or so and drop a card off at Christmas. As for my two older brothers and my father, it‚Äôs radio silence. I guess what I‚Äôm asking is, what do I do to fix this and fast, as I said I‚Äôve turned 40 this year, my parents are both 70. Time is running out, and I couldn‚Äôt imagine living my life without some kind of acceptance from my father. Or knowing he did or does love me. My heart breaks at the thought, but this is a real pickle. How can I fix a problem when the ones I need to fix it with won‚Äôt talk to me? Do I just keep ignoring their existence and put on this fa√ßade that I don‚Äôt care to my wife and 4-year-old son? What picture am I painting to my son, as he‚Äôs been guilty by association yo']

Name: 3_surgery_machine_hospital_medical
Representative_Docs: ['VIDEO: $5.5M robotic surgery system arrives at Surrey Memorial Hospital Published 12:10 pm Tuesday, January 27, 2026 By Anna Burns The da Vinci Xi System has been unpacked and calibrated and is being held in a temporary location until its permanent location is finished. Fraser Health said that it expects it to ‚Äúgo-live‚Äù later in the spring. (Fraser Health/ Contributed to Surrey Now-Leader) Health care workers pose in front of the da Vinci Xi System. (Fraser Health/ Contributed to Surrey Now-Leader) Surrey Memorial Hospital is one step closer to providing robotic-assisted surgery with the arrival of the da Vinci Xi Robotic Surgery system. It is expected to be used in surgeries in the spring. ‚ÄúWith the aid of the da Vinci Xi system, we can expand minimally invasive thoracic and foregut surgery, and we can do operations with greater precision and accuracy,‚Äù says Dr Ahmad Ashrafi, regional division head and chief of thoracic surgery for Fraser Health. ‚ÄúPatients may experience quicker recovery times, and we can carry out more complex procedures right here in Surrey, using minimally invasive techniques. This advanced technology will also help us attract and retain top surgical talent at Surrey Memorial Hospital.‚Äù Construction is underway on an operating room', 'VIDEO: $5.5M robotic surgery system arrives at Surrey Memorial Hospital Published 12:10 pm Tuesday, January 27, 2026 By Anna Burns The da Vinci Xi System has been unpacked and calibrated and is being held in a temporary location until its permanent location is finished. Name: 4_actor_actors_cast_horror
Representative_Docs: ["AP Entertainment SummaryBrief at 3:08 p.m. EST Brendan Fraser's new horizons include 'Rental Family' and rental hedgehogs BEDFORD, N.Y. (AP) ‚Äî ‚ÄúRental Family‚Äù is Brendan Fraser‚Äôs first leading role since winning the best actor Oscar for ‚ÄúThe Whale.‚Äù In it, the 56-year-old plays a struggling actor living in Japan who, out of desperation and curiosity, takes a job with an agency that hires out actors to fulfill roles in real people‚Äôs lives. In an interview, Fraser discusses his life since the Oscar win, his eye-opening experiences in Japan and what returning to the ‚ÄúMummy‚Äù series means to him. His time in Japan included a visit to a hedgehog cafe. ‚ÄúRental Family‚Äù opens Friday in theaters. Copyright 2025 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. Name: 5_immigration_britain_immigrants_diversity
Representative_Docs: ['‚ÄòUK public have tougher stance on immigration and diversity than people in US‚Äô People in the UK are less likely than their US counterparts to feel diversity strengthens society and more likely to have tougher attitudes on immigration, according to research. The findings are said to show that a common narrative about Britain being more socially liberal than America does not ring true across all issues. The National Centre for Social Research also found Reform UK voters in Britain were more likely than supporters of President Donald Trump in the US to say immigrants living in their country without permission should not be allowed to stay. While seven in 10 supporters of Mr Trump felt this way, the figure was almost eight in 10 (79%) among Reform followers. The researchers said they wanted to ‚Äúbetter understand how public attitudes in the UK compare with those in the US, and the extent of polarisation in the two countries‚Äù. Their survey found 42% of people in the UK think there should be legal efforts to deport immigrants living here without permission, compared with just a third (33%) in the US. While almost two-thirds (64%) of respondents in the US felt diversity strengthens society, only around half (49%) of the UK public agreed. Proportions were similar when', '‚ÄòUK public have tougher stance on immigration and diversity than people in US‚Äô People in the UK are less likely than their US counterparts to feel diversity strengthens society and more likely to have tougher attitudes on immigration, according to research. Name: 6_museum_world largest_tourism_exhibition
Representative_Docs: ["Egypt unveils the world's largest museum dedicated to a single civilization Egypt is inaugurating on Saturday the Grand Egyptian Museum, two decades in the making, with the aim of drawing more visitors to revitalize the country's tourist industry. Located just outside Cairo on the Giza Plateau which also includes the three pyramids and the Sphinx, the museum will be the world‚Äôs largest dedicated to a single civilization. It will display over 50,000 artifacts detailing life in ancient Egypt. World leaders, including monarchs, heads of states and governments, are set to attend the grand opening ceremony, according to the Egyptian presidency which touted the museum as ‚Äúan exceptional event in the history of human culture and civilization.‚Äù The museum is one of the megaprojects championed by President Abdel-Fattah el-Sissi since he took office in 2014. He has embarked on massive investments in infrastructure with the aim of reviving an economy weakened by decades of stagnation and battered by the unrest that followed the 2011 Arab Spring uprising. Preparations for the grand reveal have been shrouded in secrecy. The museum, which was opened for limited visits in recent years, has been closed for the past two weeks. Name: 7_fabric_pigment_carpet_colors
Representative_Docs: ['The darkest fabric ever made is now a dress Get the Popular Science daily newsletterüí° Breakthroughs, discoveries, and DIY tips sent every weekday. Terms of Service and Privacy Policy. There is black, and then there is ultrablack. The shade defined as a black that reflects less than 0.5 percent of the light that hits it, is used on everything from telescopes to cameras. This uniquely dark color is not easy to produce and may appear less black when it is viewed at an angle. To find a better way to reproduce this cool color, a team at Cornell University looked to nature. Specifically, a bird called the magnificent riflebird. The result is the darkest known fabric ever created and it is detailed in a study recently published in the journal Nature Communications. The magnificent riflebird is a large songbird and member of the bird-of-paradise family found in New Guinea and Australia. Male riflebirds are almost completely black, with a green and blue metallic sheen on their belly, throat, and crown feathers. With the help of Mary M. Ferraro and Vanya Rohwer from the Cornell Lab of Ornithology, the team studied the riflebird‚Äôs black feathers. Their plumage comes from melanin pigment paired with tightly bunched filaments called barb', "Sam's Club Is Selling a Versatile 12-Drawer Organizer That's a Serial Hobbyist's Dream Come True As a subscriber, you can share up to 3 articles each month with friends for free. Just click ‚ÄúGift this Article‚Äù on this page, then copy the link or enter their email. Gifts are exclusive to subscribers, reset monthly, and each article can be redeemed once. Parade aims to feature only the best products and services. If you buy something via one of our links, we may earn a commission. I'm calling it now: 2026 will be the year of hobbies. Whether you love crafting, building LEGO sets, sewing, painting, putting together puzzles, crocheting or all of the above, there are plenty of different hobbies you can get into this year. Of course, many of these activities require supplies that can easily get scattered about and disorganized (looking at you LEGO bricks). This may lead to more clutter and chaos in the home‚Äîsomething no one wants. That's why before you start a new hobby it can be helpful to think about a storage solution for all of your hobby essentials. Javascript is required for you to be able to read premium content. Name: 8_welfare_social security_mps_benefits
Representative_Docs: ['How much will DWP benefits and pensions rise following the budget? Benefits Budget 2025 Child Benefit Department for Work and Pensions DWP Pensions PIP Rachel Reeves Universal Credit National government Personal Finance DWP benefits including Universal Credit, Child Benefit, PIP, Carer\'s Allowance, and the State Pension are to increase in April 2026 after Rachel Reeves announced higher payments in her budget speech today. Anyone who claims DWP benefits should be in line for an increase in the next financial year, as the chancellor laid out plans to help pensioners, disabled people, parents, low earners, carers and unemployed people keep up with rising costs. Addressing MPs, Ms Reeves said: "The broken welfare system that we inherited wrote off millions of people as too sick to work and we will reform that system so that it is a system that does not count the cost of failure, but one that protects people who cannot work and empowers those who can. "We have brought back face-to-face assessments for disability benefits. Those are the face-to-face assessments that the shadow chancellor (Sir Mel Stride) got rid of when he was work and pensions secretary and our changes we have made to Universal Credit will get 15,000 people back into work, a figure con', 'How much will DWP benefits and pensions rise following the budget? Name: 9_federal reserve_florence_meeting_economy
Representative_Docs: ['Florence Press Conference Confirms ECB Remains Comfortable in Its Good Place Even a change of scenery has done nothing to change the European Central Bank‚Äôs current wait-and-see stance. Florence, where the ECB met today for its only annual meeting outside of Frankfurt, is apparently also this ‚Äôgood place‚Äô, the central bank‚Äôs well-known pseudonym for comfortably keeping interest rates on hold. ECB President Christine Lagarde even called it a ‚Äòmagnificent‚Äô place ‚Äì Florence, that is, not rates. The comments at the press conference confirmed once again that the ECB has no intention to leave its ‚Äògood place‚Äô any time soon. We had feared a rather uneventful press conference. What should we say? We hate to be right‚Ä¶ Anyhow, here are a few interesting remarks made by Lagarde: On the ECB‚Äôs risk assessment, the introductory statement had the most remarkable change compared with September. Last month, the ECB had still talked about risks to the growth outlook that had become ‚Äúmore balanced‚Äù; today, it refrained from qualifying any balance of risk. Instead, the central bank had a somewhat more extensive list of upside and downside risks to the growth outlook. Lagarde even said that some of the downside risks had abated. When asked whether this was a sign of an upcoming', 'Florence Press Conference Confirms ECB Remains Comfortable in Its Good Place Even a change of scenery has done nothing to change the European Central Bank‚Äôs current wait-and-see stance. Name: 10_strictly_itv_contestants_dancing
Representative_Docs: ["Alan Titchmarsh fans in tears as couple with '150 kids' have garden ruined in real time ITV fans couldn‚Äôt believe it when Alan Titchmarsh ‚Äúruined‚Äù a couple‚Äôs garden on Love Your Garden ‚Äì especially after elderly couple Rob and Margaret Isdale had fostered more than 150 children over the past 45 years. Their ‚Äúlovely‚Äù garden in Grantham featured on the show as Alan and his co-stars Katie Rushworth, David Domoney and Frances Tophill tried to transform it into something inspired by The Secret Garden. Initially, the space featured a large lawn area with a shed and concrete paving stones, surrounded by lush trees and greenery. Afterwards, it was transformed into a floral haven complete with a faux-ruined stone wall, stone paving stones leading in paths around the flowers, and wooden trellises around the side of the house. Read our Privacy Policy Set Daily Express as a 'Preferred Source' to get quicker", 'Strictly Come Dancing fans have same complaint as La Voix withdraws from show \'Pointless!\' Strictly Come Dancing fans have been left with the same question after it was announced La Voix has withdrawn from the competition. During Saturday (November 22) night\'s show, the remaining contestants took to the dance floor at the iconic Blackpool Tower Ballroom. Before things kicked off for Blackpool Week, presenter Tess Daly informed viewers that the drag queen ‚Äì real name Chris Dennis ‚Äì would not be returning to the competition after sustaining a foot injury. She said: "We can confirm she has very sadly had to withdraw from the competition," before revealing there would be no elimination this weekend. But this has left fans wondering why Sunday night\'s show is still airing now that there is no dance-off. Taking to social media with their queries, one wrote: "So what‚Äôs the point of Sunday‚Äôs show when everything can be done tonight #Strictly?" You', 'Strictly Come Dancing star breaks silence after concern fifth contestant would quit Strictly Come Dancing\'s Alex Kingston is poised to carry on with her dance adventure, putting to rest concerns she might have to withdraw due to injury. The 62-year-old actress had triggered concerns about a potential exit after her daughter disclosed a rib injury on social media, stating that her mother had endured the discomfort to participate in Saturday\'s programme. The Doctor Who legend, who has been dazzling audiences on the dance floor alongside partner Johannes Radebe, was swift to comfort her supporters that injuries were simply "part and parcel" of the Strictly experience, and she had absolutely no plans to retire her dancing shoes. Fleur East, host of Strictly spin-off It Takes Two, has now verified that Alex will return to the competition following last week\'s Blackpool special. Discussing their forthcoming performance, Fleur disclosed: "Alex and Johannes will be dancing a cha-cha-cha to Ring My Bell by Anita Ward."
